content: I just found that on my contributions but it has been quite a while so I didn't change a thing, as I don't remember anything wrong with it

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Goal section
* Please add a sentence to indicate the goal of the puzzle (to find out the cypher alphabet instead of decrypt the given message?).

* Please change "crypted" to "encrypted" (as "crypt" is not a verb; same reason for similar changes below).

* Please change "simple, replace" to "simple: replace".

* Please change "you" to "your".

* Please change "uncrypted" to "unencrypted".

* Please change "crypting alphabet" to "cypher alphabet" (side note: Google search shows more results for "cypher alphabet" than "cyphertext alphabet").

* Please change "crypt" to "encrypt".

* Please change "english" to "English".

* Please change "originaly" to "originally".

* Suggest to split the middle paragraph into three. The second paragraph may begin with "That works", and the third one may begin with "The likelihood of a text".

* Is the sentence "to not to make long words seem less likely, you may normalize them." relevant to this puzzle? If so, what is the way to normalize them? By using the given formula? If not, suggest to delete it to avoid confusion.

* Please explain what i and i + 1 refer to in the formula.

* Please explain how P(i, i + 1) is calculated. Or will they be found in the link you're going to include in the statement?

* What does P(Markov) = -3.1812 denote? I mean, what is the implication if the value is more negative or less negative? Can the value be zero or positive?

* The notations are kind of confusing. Correct me if I'm wrong: It seems to me that P() indicates probabilities where possible values are limited between 0 and 1. But P(Markov) is a negative value you term as "likelihood" - so P() here looks like something else and another notation should be used.

* Please change "usualy" to "usually".

* Suggest to change "calculus method" to "calculation method" (I'm not sure about this).

* Suggest to add some explanation or an example on how the likelihood figures are used in decryption.

* Please explain how the following are treated (e.g. ignored?) in the calculation of likelihood:
(a) case of letters
(b) non-letters e.g. spaces, digits and other characters

* Distribution percentages table: Please show fewer letters per line as the lines may not always be shown fully. For example, my window shows A to U only. It should look better if you use 4 lines instead of 3.

* "The complete list is given below". / "I will soon enough put a link to the whole stats": List to be added, and the last paragraph to be tidied up before the approval phase.

Input section
* Line 1 description: A bit confusing to me right now. I'll wait for more explanation as commented above before I comment on this description again.

* Please change "Everything else" to "Line 2".

* Please format "text" as a [[variable]].

* Line 2 description: A bit weird, as while it is the text to decypher, the requirement is not to decypher it. Again, I will comment on this description again later.

My comment is too long, so I'll continue in another one.

Output section
* Please indicate that the alphabet is shown in uppercase.

Constraints section
* Please format "text" as a [[variable]], without formatting "Length of the".

* Please add "1 <" in front of the constraint.

Cases
* In the last pair of cases, although there is a letter which "never appears", there is only one "unknown" letter in the alphabet. So, it can actually be deduced and included in the alphabet? (Of course, you may choose to still show it as a dot.)

Thanks.

I think I've done all that, except
* Suggest to add some explanation or an example on how the likelihood figures are used in decryption.
I'm not sure what you mean here.
As you said, normalizing isn't necessary (it can be used to make all likelihoods look more alike, not matter the size of the text) so I deleted that part and redone the tests with that in mind.

Thank you for making the changes. It's clearer now and you may ignore that comment you asked about. Below are the updated comments:

Goal section
* Please change "english" to "English".

* Please change "no-letter" to "non-letter".

* Please change "meaningfull" to "meaningful".

* Please change "it represent" to "it represents".

* Please add "." after "aren't encrypted".

* Please change "from another methods, but" to "using other methods, but in this puzzle" (change 2 words and add 3 words).

* Please explain how the case of letters is treated - is it ignored?

Input section
* Please change "programm" to "program".

Output section
* Please change "encryption" to "cypher" for consistency.

Difficulty level
* Maybe the puzzle can be classified as Hard, as no further explanation is given on how one may reduce the sample space of the potential cypher alphabets to test (except that the likelihood percentages should be used)? I'm not sure; I'm interested to see others' views on this.

Thanks.
Suggest to upload a cover picture for the puzzle.
